questions.stem: A 72-year-old retired surgeon volunteers as a medical advisor, reads the latest journals daily to maintain her knowledge, and uses voice-recording software because her handwriting has become unreliable. According to Baltes' model, this pattern best illustrates:

options.text: Disengagement theory—the surgeon is withdrawing from her primary professional role
Selection, Optimization, and Compensation (SOC)—she selects advisory roles, optimizes knowledge, and compensates with technology
Activity theory—she is substituting a new role to maintain the same activity level as middle adulthood
Socioemotional selectivity theory—she is narrowing her professional network to emotionally meaningful relationships

questions.explanation: This vignette is a classic illustration of Baltes' SOC model: Selection (choosing advisory over surgical roles), Optimization (continuing to update medical knowledge daily), and Compensation (using voice-recording software to substitute for declining fine motor skills). While the surgeon has changed roles (which could superficially resemble disengagement), the SOC framework specifically describes active, strategic adaptation. Activity theory would focus on maintaining activity level, and SST focuses on social network pruning based on emotional meaning—neither captures the strategic three-component process shown here.

questions.stem: A 75-year-old retired attorney takes significantly longer to learn a new smartphone app but remains highly articulate and effective in advising younger colleagues on complex legal matters. This pattern is best explained by:

options.text: Decline in crystallized intelligence with preservation of fluid intelligence
Decline in fluid intelligence with preservation of crystallized intelligence
Global cognitive decline affecting all intellectual domains equally
Selective decline in procedural memory with preservation of episodic memory

questions.explanation: This vignette illustrates the classic differential aging pattern of fluid versus crystallized intelligence. Learning a new app requires novel problem-solving and adaptation (fluid intelligence/Gf), which peaks in the mid-20s and declines progressively. Legal expertise, vocabulary, and accumulated knowledge represent crystallized intelligence (Gc), which remains stable or even increases through the 60s and 70s. Cognitive aging does NOT affect all domains equally—this differential pattern is one of the most fundamental findings in the psychology of aging. The vignette does not involve procedural or episodic memory.

questions.stem: According to Carstensen's socioemotional selectivity theory, the primary reason older adults have smaller social networks than younger adults is:

options.text: Age-related social withdrawal consistent with disengagement theory
Cognitive decline that makes it difficult to maintain many relationships
A motivational shift toward emotionally meaningful goals as perceived remaining time decreases
Loss of social roles through retirement and widowhood with inadequate role substitution

questions.explanation: Carstensen's socioemotional selectivity theory (SST) proposes that as people age and perceive their remaining time as limited, they shift their goals from knowledge acquisition and future-oriented pursuits to emotional regulation and emotionally meaningful experiences. This leads to deliberate pruning of social networks, retaining only the most emotionally rewarding relationships. This narrowing is NOT a sign of decline or withdrawal—it is an adaptive motivational shift driven by time perspective. Older adults actually report HIGHER satisfaction with their smaller networks. This stands in contrast to disengagement theory (mutual withdrawal) and activity theory (role substitution).

questions.stem: A patient presents with visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and mild parkinsonian features. When prescribed a low-dose typical antipsychotic, she experiences a severe adverse reaction. This presentation is most consistent with:

options.text: Alzheimer's disease
Vascular dementia
Lewy body dementia
Frontotemporal dementia

questions.explanation: Lewy body dementia is characterized by a distinctive triad: visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, and parkinsonism (motor features). A critical clinical feature is severe sensitivity to antipsychotic medications—patients with Lewy body dementia can have life-threatening reactions to neuroleptics. Alzheimer's features gradual memory loss without prominent visual hallucinations or motor symptoms. Vascular dementia shows stepwise decline after strokes. Frontotemporal dementia features personality/behavioral changes preceding memory loss, typically with younger onset (ages 45–65).

questions.stem: According to Levinson, the midlife transition occurs between ages 40 and 45 and may involve a 'midlife crisis.' Research on this concept indicates that:

options.text: A full-blown midlife crisis is a universal experience reported by the majority of adults
Only about 10–25% of adults report experiencing a crisis during middle adulthood; most undergo a more gradual transition
The midlife crisis has been entirely discredited and no adults experience significant questioning during this period
The midlife crisis occurs exclusively in men and has no parallel in women's development

questions.explanation: While Levinson proposed that the midlife transition (ages 40–45) can involve significant questioning and potential turmoil, subsequent research has shown that a full-blown 'midlife crisis' is NOT universal. Only approximately 10–25% of adults report experiencing a crisis during middle adulthood. Most adults experience a more gradual midlife transition rather than a dramatic upheaval. The concept has not been entirely discredited—some adults do experience significant distress—but it is far less common than popular culture suggests and is not exclusive to men.

questions.stem: Select all findings from Schaie's Seattle Longitudinal Study that are supported by the research evidence.

options.text: Most cognitive abilities remain stable through the mid-50s to early 60s
Perceptual speed shows the earliest and steepest decline among cognitive abilities
All cognitive abilities decline at the same rate beginning in the 30s
Higher education and an active lifestyle are associated with reduced cognitive decline
Individual differences in cognitive aging are minimal, with virtually all adults following the same trajectory

questions.explanation: Schaie's Seattle Longitudinal Study, the most comprehensive investigation of adult intellectual development, found: (1) most cognitive abilities remain stable through the mid-50s to early 60s; (2) perceptual speed shows the earliest and steepest decline; (3) verbal abilities and inductive reasoning are relatively well-preserved; (4) individual differences in cognitive aging are ENORMOUS (not minimal); and (5) factors associated with reduced decline include higher education, active lifestyle, flexible personality, stimulating environment, and absence of cardiovascular disease. Cognitive abilities do NOT all decline at the same rate—differential decline is a key finding.

questions.stem: Select all characteristics that accurately describe Arnett's concept of emerging adulthood.

options.text: It spans approximately ages 18–25 and is considered a distinct developmental stage in industrialized societies
It is characterized by identity exploration, instability, self-focus, feeling 'in between,' and a sense of possibilities
It is universally applicable across all cultures, socioeconomic groups, and historical periods
Critics note it may primarily describe the experiences of privileged populations in Western, industrialized nations
It was proposed by Erikson as the transition between identity and intimacy stages

questions.explanation: Arnett (2000) proposed that emerging adulthood (ages 18–25) is a distinct developmental stage characterized by five features: identity exploration (especially in love, work, and worldviews), instability (frequent changes in residence, relationships, employment), self-focus, feeling 'in between' adolescence and adulthood, and a sense of possibilities. The concept has been criticized for applying primarily to privileged populations in Western industrialized nations—it may not describe those who assume adult responsibilities early due to economic necessity. The concept was proposed by Arnett, not Erikson.

questions.stem: Select all accurate statements about Kübler-Ross's five-stage model of dying.

options.text: The five stages are: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance
The model has been criticized for implying a fixed, universal sequence that all dying individuals follow
Contemporary research confirms that the stages occur in the exact order Kübler-Ross described, with no exceptions
The model is best understood as describing common emotional reactions to dying rather than a prescriptive progression
People may move back and forth between stages and may not experience all stages

questions.explanation: Kübler-Ross (1969) proposed five stages of dying: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance. While widely known and influential, the model has been significantly criticized for implying a fixed, universal sequence. Contemporary research shows that: not all individuals experience all stages; the stages do not necessarily occur in the described order; and people may move back and forth between stages. The model is best understood as describing common emotional reactions rather than a prescriptive or invariant progression. Clinicians should avoid rigidly applying this framework.

questions.stem: Select all principles that Baltes identified as foundational to the lifespan developmental psychology perspective.

options.text: Development is lifelong—it continues from conception to death with no single age period holding supremacy
Development is multidirectional, involving both growth (gains) and decline (losses) at any given point
Development follows a single universal trajectory that is identical across all cultures and historical periods
Cognitive and behavioral capacities show plasticity—they can be modified through training at any age, though plasticity decreases with age
Development is influenced by historical and cultural context, with different cohorts developing differently

questions.explanation: Baltes articulated several foundational principles of lifespan developmental psychology: (1) Development is lifelong, not limited to childhood; (2) Development is multidirectional, involving both gains and losses at every point; (3) Plasticity exists at all ages, though it decreases with age; (4) Development is historically embedded, with different cohorts developing differently due to different historical circumstances; (5) Development is contextual, shaped by age-graded, history-graded, and non-normative influences; (6) Development is multidisciplinary. Development does NOT follow a single universal trajectory—the emphasis on context, history, and plasticity explicitly contradicts such a view.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately distinguish normal cognitive aging from dementia.

options.text: Normal aging involves slowed processing speed and occasional word-finding difficulties that do not significantly impair daily functioning
Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) represents a transitional state where decline exceeds normal aging but does not meet dementia criteria
Depression in older adults can produce cognitive impairment that mimics dementia ('pseudodementia'), which is treatable and reversible
Approximately 10–15% of individuals with MCI progress to dementia annually, though some remain stable or revert to normal
Normal aging and dementia exist on a continuum, making it impossible to distinguish between them through neuropsychological assessment

questions.explanation: Normal aging involves predictable changes (slowed processing speed, reduced working memory, word-finding difficulties) that do not significantly impair independent functioning. MCI is a transitional state with decline exceeding normal expectations but not meeting dementia criteria; approximately 10–15% of MCI cases progress to dementia annually, though some stabilize or improve. Depression can cause 'pseudodementia'—a treatable condition mimicking dementia. Neuropsychological assessment IS essential and effective in distinguishing normal aging from MCI and various dementia subtypes—the claim that distinction is impossible is incorrect.

questions.stem: Match each of Erikson's adult psychosocial stages with its corresponding virtue.
questions.explanation: Erikson's psychosocial stages each produce a specific virtue upon successful resolution: Intimacy vs. Isolation (young adulthood, ages 18–40) yields Love—the capacity for committed, intimate relationships. Generativity vs. Stagnation (middle adulthood, ages 40–65) yields Care—concern for guiding the next generation. Ego Integrity vs. Despair (late adulthood, 65+) yields Wisdom—acceptance of one's life as meaningful. Identity vs. Role Confusion (adolescence) yields Fidelity—loyalty to chosen values and people.

questions.stem: Match each dementia type with its most distinguishing clinical feature.

columns.text: Gradual progressive decline with early memory loss, neurofibrillary tangles, and amyloid plaques
Stepwise decline following cerebrovascular events, associated with cardiovascular risk factors
Visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, parkinsonism, and severe antipsychotic sensitivity
Personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy) preceding memory loss, often with younger onset

questions.explanation: Each dementia type has distinguishing features critical for differential diagnosis: Alzheimer's disease (most common, ~60–70% of dementias) features gradual onset with early memory loss and characteristic neuropathology (neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques). Vascular dementia (second most common) shows stepwise decline following strokes and is associated with cardiovascular risk factors. Lewy body dementia (third most common) is characterized by visual hallucinations, fluctuating cognition, parkinsonian features, and dangerous sensitivity to antipsychotic medications. Frontotemporal dementia features personality and behavioral changes preceding memory loss, with typically younger onset (ages 45–65).

questions.stem: For each memory system, select ALL accurate descriptions of how it is affected by normal aging.

columns.text: Relatively stable or increases with age
Free recall affected more than recognition

questions.explanation: Normal aging affects memory systems differentially: Working memory shows decline (reduced capacity and processing speed). Episodic memory (recall of specific events) declines, with free recall affected more than recognition memory. Semantic memory (general knowledge, vocabulary) is relatively stable and may even increase with age. Procedural memory (how to do things) is well-preserved across the lifespan. This pattern of differential preservation is a key finding in cognitive aging research and important for clinical assessment.

questions.stem: For each theory of aging, select ALL propositions or claims that accurately characterize the theory.

columns.text: Mutual withdrawal between individual and society is natural and adaptive
Maintaining middle-adulthood activity levels promotes successful aging
Perceived limited time drives a shift toward emotionally meaningful goals
Strategic narrowing of goals, resource investment, and use of alternative means

questions.explanation: Disengagement theory (Cumming & Henry, 1961) proposed that mutual withdrawal between aging individuals and society is natural and adaptive, though it has been widely criticized and largely discredited. Activity theory (Havighurst, 1961) proposes that maintaining the activities and social connections of middle adulthood promotes successful aging. Socioemotional selectivity theory (Carstensen, 1991) posits that perceived limited remaining time drives a motivational shift toward emotionally meaningful goals and relationship pruning. Baltes' SOC model describes strategic selection of goals, optimization of resources for chosen goals, and compensation using alternative means when resources decline.

questions.stem: In Baltes' dual-process model of cognitive aging, {{blank1}} represent the biology-based 'hardware' of the mind and parallel {{blank2}} in the Cattell-Horn model. {{blank3}} represent the culture-based 'software' of the mind and parallel {{blank4}} in the Cattell-Horn model.

options.text: cognitive mechanics
cognitive pragmatics
procedural knowledge
episodic memory systems
crystallized intelligence (Gc)
fluid intelligence (Gf)
general intelligence (g)
emotional intelligence (EQ)
cognitive mechanics
cognitive pragmatics
working memory systems
executive functions
fluid intelligence (Gf)
crystallized intelligence (Gc)
perceptual speed
spatial intelligence

questions.explanation: Baltes' dual-process model distinguishes between: (1) Cognitive mechanics—the biology-based 'hardware' of the mind, including processing speed, working memory, and pattern recognition. Mechanics parallel fluid intelligence (Gf) in the Cattell-Horn model and show normative decline from early adulthood. (2) Cognitive pragmatics—the culture-based 'software' of the mind, including accumulated knowledge, expertise, and practical wisdom. Pragmatics parallel crystallized intelligence (Gc) and can be maintained or even increase into old age. A key insight is that pragmatics can partially compensate for declining mechanics, but only up to a point.

questions.stem: The Dual Process Model of bereavement (Stroebe & Schut, 1999) proposes that healthy grieving involves oscillation between {{blank1}} and {{blank2}}. Approximately {{blank3}} of bereaved individuals develop prolonged grief disorder, which is characterized by persistent longing and functional impairment lasting beyond {{blank4}}.

options.text: loss-oriented coping (processing the emotional pain of loss)
denial-oriented coping (refusing to acknowledge the loss)
anger-oriented coping (expressing rage at the deceased)
avoidance-oriented coping (suppressing all grief-related thoughts)
acceptance-oriented coping (reaching the final stage of grief)
restoration-oriented coping (attending to life changes and rebuilding)
bargaining-oriented coping (negotiating with existential forces)
meaning-oriented coping (finding spiritual significance in the loss)
2 weeks
3 months
12 months (DSM-5-TR) or 6 months (ICD-11)
5 years

questions.explanation: The Dual Process Model (Stroebe & Schut, 1999) proposes that healthy bereavement involves dynamic oscillation between two orientations: loss-oriented coping (confronting and processing the emotional pain of the loss) and restoration-oriented coping (attending to practical life changes, new roles, and rebuilding). Exclusively dwelling on loss or exclusively avoiding it are both maladaptive. Approximately 7–10% of bereaved individuals develop prolonged grief disorder, characterized by persistent longing, difficulty accepting the death, and functional impairment lasting beyond 12 months (DSM-5-TR) or 6 months (ICD-11).

questions.stem: A 78-year-old woman has a smaller social network than she did at age 40 but reports higher satisfaction with her relationships. She prioritizes spending time with close family and lifelong friends over meeting new people or joining new social groups.

options.text: Perception of remaining time as limited, shifting motivational priorities
Deliberate prioritization of emotionally meaningful relationships over information-seeking relationships
Cognitive decline making it impossible to maintain larger social networks
Mutual withdrawal between the individual and society as described by disengagement theory
Carstensen's socioemotional selectivity theory
Cumming and Henry's disengagement theory
Havighurst's activity theory
Younger adults experimentally induced to perceive limited time will show similar social preferences to older adults
The smaller network represents an adaptive motivational shift, not a sign of social decline
The woman's social satisfaction will continue to decrease as her network shrinks further
Forced expansion of the social network would improve her well-being

questions.explanation: This vignette illustrates Carstensen's socioemotional selectivity theory (SST). The contributing factors are: perception of limited remaining time shifting motivational priorities, and deliberate prioritization of emotionally meaningful relationships. SST specifically argues this is NOT due to cognitive decline or social withdrawal—it is an active, adaptive choice. Key predictions of SST include: younger adults primed to perceive limited time show similar social preferences (a finding that has been experimentally confirmed), and the smaller network is adaptive, not pathological. Forcing network expansion would be inconsistent with the theory and unlikely to improve well-being.

questions.stem: An 80-year-old man presents with gradual, progressive memory decline over 3 years. He forgets recent conversations, has difficulty navigating familiar places, and shows personality changes and word-finding problems. His MoCA score is 18/30 and brain imaging reveals hippocampal atrophy.

options.text: Gradual, progressive onset with early and prominent memory loss for recent events
Hippocampal atrophy on neuroimaging consistent with neurodegenerative pathology
Stepwise decline following identifiable cerebrovascular events
Prominent visual hallucinations and fluctuating cognition as the presenting features
Alzheimer's disease
Vascular dementia
Frontotemporal dementia
Screen for treatable conditions that can mimic dementia, including depression, thyroid dysfunction, and vitamin B12 deficiency
Comprehensive neuropsychological assessment should evaluate memory, executive function, language, and visuospatial skills
Prescribe high-dose antipsychotic medication as the first-line treatment
No further assessment is needed once the MoCA score indicates impairment

questions.explanation: This presentation—gradual progressive memory decline, difficulty with recent events and navigation, personality changes, word-finding problems, low MoCA score, and hippocampal atrophy—is most consistent with Alzheimer's disease, the most common neurodegenerative cause of dementia (~60–70% of cases). The gradual onset rules out vascular dementia (stepwise decline). The prominent memory loss rules out frontotemporal dementia (personality/behavioral changes precede memory loss) and Lewy body dementia (visual hallucinations and fluctuating cognition). Clinically, treatable mimics (depression/pseudodementia, thyroid dysfunction, B12 deficiency) must be screened for, and comprehensive neuropsychological assessment is essential.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe Baltes' contributions to lifespan developmental psychology.
questions.passage: Paul Baltes was a foundational figure in lifespan developmental psychology. [He proposed that development is lifelong, multidirectional, and involves both gains and losses at every point in the lifespan]. [The SOC model describes three interrelated processes: Selection (choosing goals), Optimization (investing resources in chosen goals), and Compensation (using alternative means when resources decline)]. [Baltes demonstrated that wisdom automatically and reliably increases with age, with older adults consistently scoring higher than younger adults]. [Cognitive mechanics (biology-based) parallel fluid intelligence and show decline with age, while cognitive pragmatics (culture-based) parallel crystallized intelligence and can be maintained]. [The Berlin Wisdom Paradigm defines wisdom as expert knowledge about the fundamental pragmatics of life, encompassing factual knowledge, procedural knowledge, lifespan contextualism, value relativism, and management of uncertainty]. [Baltes argued that development is determined exclusively by biology, with culture and history playing no significant role].

highlightableSegments.text: He proposed that development is lifelong, multidirectional, and involves both gains and losses at every point in the lifespan
The SOC model describes three interrelated processes: Selection (choosing goals), Optimization (investing resources in chosen goals), and Compensation (using alternative means when resources decline)
Baltes demonstrated that wisdom automatically and reliably increases with age, with older adults consistently scoring higher than younger adults
Cognitive mechanics (biology-based) parallel fluid intelligence and show decline with age, while cognitive pragmatics (culture-based) parallel crystallized intelligence and can be maintained

The Berlin Wisdom Paradigm defines wisdom as expert knowledge about the fundamental pragmatics of life, encompassing factual knowledge, procedural knowledge, lifespan contextualism, value relativism, and management of uncertainty
Baltes argued that development is determined exclusively by biology, with culture and history playing no significant role

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are accurate descriptions of Baltes' contributions. Statement 3 is false—Baltes' research found that wisdom does NOT automatically increase with age; older adults do not consistently score higher than younger adults, though those with rich life experiences, high intelligence, and openness have the greatest potential for wisdom. Statement 6 is the opposite of Baltes' position—he emphasized that development is historically embedded, contextual, and shaped by the interaction of biological, cultural, and individual factors.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the psychology of death, dying, and bereavement.
questions.passage: Understanding death and dying is essential for clinical practice. [Kübler-Ross proposed five stages of dying: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance, though contemporary research indicates these are not a fixed or universal sequence]. [The Dual Process Model of bereavement proposes that healthy grieving involves oscillation between loss-oriented and restoration-oriented coping]. [Prolonged grief disorder affects approximately 7–10% of bereaved individuals and is characterized by persistent longing and functional impairment]. [All bereaved individuals who experience intense grief within the first month should be diagnosed with prolonged grief disorder]. [Kübler-Ross's model is best understood as describing common emotional reactions to dying rather than a prescriptive progression]. [Research confirms that a single, linear progression through the five stages is the norm for dying patients].

highlightableSegments.text: Kübler-Ross proposed five stages of dying: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, and Acceptance, though contemporary research indicates these are not a fixed or universal sequence
The Dual Process Model of bereavement proposes that healthy grieving involves oscillation between loss-oriented and restoration-oriented coping
Prolonged grief disorder affects approximately 7–10% of bereaved individuals and is characterized by persistent longing and functional impairment
All bereaved individuals who experience intense grief within the first month should be diagnosed with prolonged grief disorder
Kübler-Ross's model is best understood as describing common emotional reactions to dying rather than a prescriptive progression
Research confirms that a single, linear progression through the five stages is the norm for dying patients

questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, 3, and 5 are accurate. Kübler-Ross proposed the five stages while contemporary research shows they are not fixed or universal. The Dual Process Model describes healthy oscillation between loss-oriented and restoration-oriented coping. Prolonged grief disorder affects 7–10% of bereaved individuals. Statement 4 is false—intense early grief is normal, not pathological; prolonged grief disorder requires symptoms lasting beyond 12 months (DSM-5-TR) or 6 months (ICD-11). Statement 6 is false—research does not confirm linear progression; people move back and forth between stages and may not experience all of them.

questions.stem: Arrange Kübler-Ross's five stages of dying in the order she originally proposed them.

items.text: Denial ('This can't be happening to me')
Anger ('Why me? This isn't fair!')
Bargaining ('If I could just have more time...')
Depression (mourning impending losses)
Acceptance (coming to terms with reality)
[Note: Research shows this sequence is not fixed or universal]

questions.explanation: Kübler-Ross (1969) proposed five stages of dying in this order: (1) Denial—initial shock and disbelief; (2) Anger—frustration and questioning 'why me?'; (3) Bargaining—attempting to negotiate for more time; (4) Depression—mourning impending losses and withdrawing; (5) Acceptance—coming to terms with the reality of death. However, it is critically important to know that contemporary research has shown this sequence is NOT fixed, NOT universal, and NOT necessarily sequential. People may skip stages, experience them in different orders, or move back and forth between them.

questions.stem: Arrange Levinson's adult developmental periods in chronological order from earliest to latest.

items.text: Early Adult Transition (17–22): Moving from preadult world into early adulthood
Entering the Adult World (22–28): Building first adult life structure
Age-30 Transition (28–33): Reassessing and modifying first life structure
Midlife Transition (40–45): Questioning earlier choices, confronting mortality
Middle Adulthood (45–60): Building new life structure based on midlife reassessment
Late Adult Transition (60–65): Adjusting to retirement, physical decline, legacy

questions.explanation: Levinson's model of adult development describes a sequence of eras with transitional periods: (1) Early Adult Transition (17–22)—separating from the preadult world; (2) Entering the Adult World (22–28)—building initial adult life structure; (3) Age-30 Transition (28–33)—reassessing the first life structure; (4) Midlife Transition (40–45)—confronting mortality and unfulfilled dreams (only 10–25% experience a 'crisis'); (5) Middle Adulthood (45–60)—building new structures; (6) Late Adult Transition (60–65)—preparing for late adulthood. These periods reflect the construction, modification, and rebuilding of 'life structures.'

questions.stem: A researcher tracks fluid intelligence (Gf) and crystallized intelligence (Gc) across the adult lifespan using standardized cognitive assessments.
questions.question: Which conclusion about cognitive aging is best supported by this data pattern?

options.text: Both Gf and Gc decline at the same rate beginning in the mid-20s
Fluid intelligence peaks in the mid-20s and declines progressively, while crystallized intelligence remains stable or increases through the 60s–70s before modest decline
Crystallized intelligence peaks earlier than fluid intelligence
Both types of intelligence are unaffected by aging until after age 75

questions.explanation: The data illustrates the classic differential aging trajectory of Gf and Gc, one of the most well-established findings in cognitive aging research (Cattell, 1963; Horn & Cattell, 1967). Fluid intelligence peaks in the mid-20s and shows gradual, steady decline beginning in the 30s that accelerates in later adulthood. Crystallized intelligence increases through education and experience, remains stable or increases through middle adulthood and often into the 60s–70s, and shows only modest decline in later life. These two forms of intelligence do NOT decline at the same rate, and Gc peaks later than Gf.

questions.stem: A study examines age-related changes in social network size and reported relationship satisfaction across the adult lifespan.
questions.question: Which theory of aging best accounts for the inverse relationship between social network size and relationship satisfaction shown in the data?

options.text: Disengagement theory—decreased satisfaction drives withdrawal from social relationships
Activity theory—maintaining activity compensates for shrinking networks
Socioemotional selectivity theory—older adults deliberately prune networks to retain only the most emotionally rewarding relationships
Cognitive decline theory—memory impairment prevents maintenance of social connections

questions.explanation: The data shows an inverse pattern: as social network size decreases across adulthood, relationship satisfaction INCREASES. This paradox is precisely what Carstensen's socioemotional selectivity theory (SST) predicts and explains. As people age and perceive remaining time as limited, they shift from knowledge-seeking to emotion-regulating goals, deliberately pruning their social networks to retain only the most emotionally meaningful relationships. The result is a smaller but more satisfying network. Disengagement theory would not predict increased satisfaction. Activity theory focuses on maintaining activity levels, not network pruning. The pattern is not explained by cognitive decline.

questions.stem: Categorize each component of the Rubinstein piano illustration as demonstrating Selection, Optimization, or Compensation in Baltes' SOC model.

items.text: Reducing the number of pieces in his performance repertoire
Practicing the selected pieces more frequently and intensively than before
Slowing down before fast passages to create a contrast effect that makes fast sections appear faster
Choosing to focus only on compositions that showcase his remaining strengths
Investing more rehearsal hours per piece to achieve the highest possible quality
Using tempo manipulation to mask reduced motor speed—an alternative strategy to maintain the audience's perception of virtuosity

questions.explanation: Baltes used the pianist Arthur Rubinstein as the classic illustration of SOC in action during his 80s: SELECTION—reducing the number of pieces in his repertoire (loss-based selection) and choosing compositions that showcased his remaining strengths (elective selection). OPTIMIZATION—practicing the selected pieces more frequently and intensively to achieve the highest possible quality within chosen domains. COMPENSATION—slowing down before fast passages to create a perceptual contrast that made fast sections appear faster than they were, and using tempo manipulation as an alternative strategy to maintain perceived virtuosity despite reduced motor speed.

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical presentation as most consistent with Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, or frontotemporal dementia.

items.text: An 80-year-old with gradual progressive memory loss, hippocampal atrophy, and difficulty recognizing family members
A 70-year-old with a history of multiple strokes who shows abrupt, stepwise cognitive decline
A 55-year-old whose family reports dramatic personality changes, social disinhibition, and apathy with relatively preserved memory
A 78-year-old with brain imaging showing amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, with progressive word-finding difficulties
A 68-year-old with uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes who shows cognitive decline correlated with white matter lesions on MRI
A 52-year-old executive fired for making inappropriate sexual comments and impulsive financial decisions, with frontal and temporal lobe atrophy on imaging

questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease: gradual progressive memory loss (especially recent events), hippocampal atrophy, amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, progressive language difficulties. Typically presents in older adults. Vascular dementia: stepwise decline following cerebrovascular events (strokes), associated with cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes), white matter lesions on imaging. Frontotemporal dementia: typically younger onset (ages 45–65), prominent personality and behavioral changes (disinhibition, apathy, impulsivity) PRECEDING memory loss, frontal and temporal lobe atrophy. Includes Pick's disease as a subtype.
